content: Awesome clash!! Most fun clash I've played in a while.

I just got this as a clash, and noticed an issue. Someone submitted some Python code that got 90%. I decided to test their code here in the IDE because I suspected (correctly) that they got 100% on the test cases.

The issue is that Validator 3 is the only test or validator that has three input phrases that all have a space connecting them to the commonWord. This means that some algorithms include the space in the common word and forget to remove it when they print the Answer.

It would be best if you edited a test case to match this, so  that clashers can fix this problem in-clash, rather than only realise after submitting what they thought was a 100% submission.

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: It will be difficult for most people but its easily brute force-able so nice clash.

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: It's a good puzzle and makes you think. There are multiple ways to solve it. Though most solutions can't be done in 5 mins imo.

As most said, it is indeed harder than most clashes. But still feasible.

One thing tho, not sure if it was wanted but, there is no test to validate that the commonWord appears in all 3 inputs. I mean, you can find the commonWord from only 2 inputs. 

Take your solution for example and omit the bool2 check on line 59 and it still works.
bool bool3 = bool0 && bool1;// && bool2;

Such test might be something like ...
BLACKBOARD
WOODEN BOARD
WOODEN OAR

Then again, it would make it even harder ðŸ¤¨

Here's me pleading the case for how it can be solved in 15 minutes in a straight-forward way:
(1) Take the first phrase:
  Put all substrings of it (that don't contain a space) into List1
(2) Go thru all items in List1:
  If an item is in all 3 inputs, then put that item in List2.
(3) Find the longest item in List2.  Thats the common word.
(4) remove common word from the 3 inputs and print what's left
(5) print the common word

I do realize this is on the harder-side but it is solvable.

Approve me, y'all :) :) :)

Interesting, but might be bit difficult to achieve in 5 mins unless they are ready know what they are doing, because of a few edge cases that make it tricky.
Took me some time to work out the output format, and remove the extra spaces properly from the first output line.

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: This is a fun, creative challenge that solves a real-world problem that is interesting and relatable. I was able to solve it in 6 minutes using a mix of Regex and simple iteration, and I'm sure 5 minutes is possible for faster coders.

I like this clash.This is a classical problem,the longest common substring of multiple strings.
In fact,this problem can be solved in O(abc) using dynamic programming which means that the strings can be 100 chars long so your solutions won't work.
btw,it can be solved in O(n log n) where n=a+b+c using suffix data structures,which means that the strings can be 100000 chars long.
So,I suggest to add the constraint that the length of the strings in the input won't exceed 50.

This one seems a bit hard. I suggest that in your input test cases, the words should be spaced with the keyword to make programming the solution easier. For instance, a space should be inserted in "BATHROOM" to get this input:

BATH ROOM
BATH SALTS
BLOOD BATH

Clash is interesting but it took me 23 minutes to get to the correct answer.
I'm way past the 5 minutes mark. It may be a bit complicated for a clash?
ALL: I'm going to pull this back from "Ready" to "Work in Progress" as  I believe some changes might be needed (per the feedback I got today).
I like this challenge. There is a note: I think CoC should have the most simple output format to save time. For example: "Answer: bath". Words with different case also complicate matters.

I do like the clash, but I am slightly hesitant about approving; it took me about 10 minutes and a couple of errors, difficulty feels at least above average for clashes. I will wait for some other reactions to get more comfortable with clicking 'solvable within 5 minutes'.

What partly took some minutes for me is that I started looking to it as reverse, and from that saw the pattern of that always at least once a common word separated by space was included - but in IDE I realized that that information is technically not known to Fastest and Shortest players, so I should not use that knowledge. So, I was a bit hesitant on my coding approach (can I use the space or not). What might have helped me is a kind of final answer on this in the Statement, like 'Every case has a mix of phrases with and without space', or, if you do not want that to be a given, 'Cases can be a mixture of phrases with or without space' (these suggestions are definitely not perfect, but I hope you understand the gist). -- But maybe that is only a solution for the special case in which someone starts reverse and moves to fastest (like me), that in reality will never happen.

Thanks for the feedback and I'm glad you like it generally.

I agree re the difficulty, but I don't think it's hard enough to be a Classic Easy puzzle, do you?   And those are really my only choices, so what to do?

I say "words/phrases" : dont you think that implies enough that it could be 1 or more words.  I mean, a phrase by definition is more than 1 word (i.e., contains a space).  I want to be clear, without being repetitive.

Thanks.  I'm glad you like it and thanks for the feedback...
My reasoning was:
â€£To keep it like Wikipedia had it in their examples
â€£For things like Supreme Court and Chris Pine, it would be weird to not have that capitalized.

But I do see what you mean.  Let me think about that trade-off, especially to keep it under the 5-minute goal.
I simplified it and added a few more test cases.  And I think it is ready now

It's a tough clash if you don't have much experience with pattern matching in strings. I was able to solve it in 6 minutes using Regexp though, so I think it's still a valid clash, just would be harder than most.

I appreciate the feedback but donâ€™t you think that would make it way too easy?

And also that itâ€™s not reflecting an actual task.
For example: a programmer shouldnâ€™t expect input that requires effort from the user, like having the user divide a compound word into 2 words, such as â€œscholar shipâ€ or â€œkey boardâ€ or â€œbe friendâ€
Thanks!

I tried it again using regex after reading StepBack13's comment, and that seems a much better option. It's much shorted and faster, but required decent knowledge of regex.
Approving.

Not sure that was well explained.
I just mean there is no false positive in some way.
Thanks!!
Thank you

Thanks for the feedback.  

I have now changed
"FISHBOWL" (no space)
to 
"FISH BOWL" (with space) 
(for test3)
Nice, that should fix the issue. Might be worth mentioning in the statement that trailing/leading spaces are to be removed too.

Ugh.... you'd think we could assume, but probably not :(  
I added a line so that it now says

Output
Line 1: The question, with the words separated by /
Line 2: Answer: commonWord
(remove all trailing/leading spaces)

Hopefully that covers all the bases :)  (If you have other thoughts, tell me)

Right. I actually spent some time doing this for a real project that I did. (It still needs a bit more work, but here it is if you want to have a look)

I found this approach basically works.
And I guess Iâ€™m not trying to find all the edge cases.

Good observation tho 

https://openprocessing.org/sketch/1671078

Oh I see, that's the reversed puzzle of this.

From what I understand, the commonWord should always be at the beginning or then end. At least not in the middle of another word. Maybe this specification might be added to the statement.

I have now put everything in in caps.
That addresses your concern and my counter-concern :)

Better now, right ?
Better. I wouldn't make it in 15 minutes, but faster programmers can.

I'll put on my active "Lisa's list of Ideas" the idea of maybe doing a more complex version of this as a classic puzzle at some point, incorporating your ideas.

But I think for now, I'll keep it as a Clash, and I simplified the case-issue.

Better, now right?

I have considered the word/phrase issue you bring up, but I think it's clear enough, especially since a player can easily see an example that has a word and a phrase.

I imagine that list of ideas is pretty long, seeing the steady rate at which you supply creative submissions. 

The combination of statement and example make the task clear quite fast, so all time can be spent on coding. 5 minutes will be tight, but there are 15 minutes available anyway :-). Your modifications like all Caps and including a case without spaces do shave of some seconds of hesitation on what methods to use, while you stay very much true to the original idea and the origin, which is admirable as well.
